title: Move Me No Mountain
text:
"Move Me No Mountain" is a song written by <a href="Jerry%20Ragovoy">Jerry Ragovoy</a> and <a href="Aaron%20Schroeder">Aaron Schroeder</a>. It was originally recorded in 1974 by <a href="In%20Heat%20%28Love%20Unlimited%20album%29">Love Unlimited</a>, a group organized and produced by <a href="Barry%20White">Barry White</a>. In 1975, Ragovoy arranged and produced a recording of the song by <a href="Dionne%20Warwick">Dionne Warwick</a>. Warwick's version used a slightly different melody in the song's chorus than the melody sung by Love Unlimited, and this variation has been used on subsequent recordings of the song. In 1980, <a href="Naughty%20%28Chaka%20Khan%20album%29">Chaka Khan</a> recorded a version of the song with production by <a href="Arif%20Mardin">Arif Mardin</a>.
Soul II Soul version.
"Move Me No Mountain" was recorded in 1992 by British R&B band <a href="Soul%20II%20Soul">Soul II Soul</a> and released as the second single from their third album, "Volume III Just Right". It features British singer <a href="Kofi%20%28musician%29">Kofi</a> (a.k.a. Carol Simms) and was a moderate hit in Europe. The song was a Top 10 hit in Greece and Portugal, peaking at number seven and ten. In the UK, it reached number 31. Outside Europe, it peaked at number 29 on the "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" <a href="Dance%20Club%20Songs">Dance Club Songs</a> chart in the US and was a Top 40 hit in New Zealand. The accompanying black-and-white <a href="music%20video">music video</a> features Kofi performing the song behind or in front of a <a href="waterfall">waterfall</a>.
Critical reception.
<a href="Larry%20Flick">Larry Flick</a> from "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" wrote that "empowered with the silky tones of new vocalist <a href="Kofi%20%28musician%29">Kofi</a>, second single from "Just Right" is a hearty mix of the act's signature nouveau <a href="Soul%20music">soul</a> and state-of-the-charts <a href="House%20music">house</a> beats." He also noted English DJ <a href="Joey%20Negro">Joey Negro</a>'s "chipper remixes." John Martinucci from the "<a href="Gavin%20Report">Gavin Report</a>" deemed it a "laid back house-flavored track with Kofi's smooth vocals", adding that former <a href="Snap%21">Snap!</a> member <a href="Penny%20Ford">Penny Ford</a> "assists with background vocals." Andy Beevers from "<a href="Music%20Week">Music Week</a>" viewed it as one of the "standout" tracks of the album, declaring it as "an obvious choice", featuring "sweet soulful vocals". Orla Swift from "<a href="Record-Journal">Record-Journal</a>" described it as "<a href="Gospel%20music">gospel</a>-inflected" and also she picked it as one of the album's "strongest cuts". Miranda Sawyer from "<a href="Select%20%28magazine%29">Select</a>" wrote that it "skips along very nicely — sweet lovers' rock vocals (from <a href="reggae">reggae</a> star Kofi) soaring over Soul II Soul's effortlessly clubby beat." Another editor, David Lubich said that it shows "a glimpse of vocal talent".
